intro: Agalinis tenuifolia var. parviflora, commonly known as the narrowleaf false foxglove, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Orobanchaceae family, which includes parasitic and hemiparasitic species. The plant typically grows in open, disturbed habitats such as roadsides and sandy soils. Its flowers are tubular and usually pink or purple, with two lips, and bloom from late spring to early summer. The leaves are narrow and opposite, contributing to its distinctive appearance.
